Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 08:34AM baywatcher wrote: Lulu- I wish that I had done more research on DCIS before I ever consented to surgery. I relied too much on the docs and nurses and they scared the crap out of me. I remember the time between my diagnosis and my surgery and how hard my heart pounded...I thought it was going to pound out of my chest. I had so much fear. Anyway, the day of my surgery, as I was sitting in the waiting room, I picked up a TIME magazine. On the cover of the magazine, the story title was "Are we overtreating breast cancer?" and it was about DCIS. I think it was an omen to me...but one that I didn't listen to. I called my doctor down before my surgery and she took the magazine away from me and told me that it didn't apply to me as I was grade 3. So I went ahead with my surgery. I had no history of cancer in my family (that I know of). My DCIS was found on a routine mammogram. I went to a support group which is led by a retired M.D.. By this time I had done more reading up on DCIS and really wished that I hadn't done my surgery. The doctor told me that they did a study in another country (I think Sweden) where they did an autopsy on everyone after death. They found that somewhere near 50% of the women that died of a cause other than breast cancer had DCIS in their breasts. Finding that info out after the fact really sent me over the edge. I have been battling severe depression over this for about 18 months now. I have since found out that there was a study about 20 years ago that found that 25% of women that undergo mastectomies have depression. I guess that I am in the 25% group. It is my opinion that DCIS (especially low grade) is overtreated. However, everyone must do what they think is best for them and their own fear factor. I totally understand how you feel but remember, once you have the mastectomy, you live with it for the rest of your life. And no one ever told me about the depression. It is hard to believe that the mind can make you feel so bad. I am starting to do better finally, but for a while I wasn't sure that I was going to make it. The depression (for me) has been much worse than the fear. Good luck to you what ever you decide.

Posts.Title: A Diagnosis Without Surgery :( prettypink prettypink

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 06:53PM baywatcher wrote: JoJo- I totally understand about not wanting to do conventional treatments. I don't want to do conventional treatments either. But how about trying some alternative and/or holistic methods? I am a big believer in nutrition. You can go to the library and find numerous books on nutrition. My favorite is "The China Study". Also "Anti-Cancer" and "Crazy Sexy Cancer" and there are lots more. When I first found out I had cancer and my friend suggested a macrobiotic diet, I thought she was nuts. I told her that the doctors would know if diet worked and everyone would do it. So I didn't make any changes in my life and got cancer again. It was a wake up call the second time. I started researching nutrition and have found that there is something to it. This is the treatment that I have chosen. I have had surgery and lost both of my breasts. I don't want any more conventional treatment. I don't want scans or anything else. I just want to do everything in my power to be as healthy as possible and if that doesn't work for me then at least I know I have tried. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 03:39AM baywatcher wrote: There was recently an article in the New York Times and I think you can find it on this site under Do Mammograms result in over treatment? I would do a lot of thinking before I would do a lumpectomy or rads or any other treatment for this. Only you can decide but I lost my breast to this 5 years ago and still to this day feel that I was over treated. Others on this board will not agree with me. It is my own opinion but If I could do a redo, I would do a lot of research before I proceeded. This is exactly how my nightmare began. I was so scared that I couldn't think straight. You have time. Do lots of research and don't let them push you into something that you will regret later.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 10:13PM baywatcher wrote: Hi Pill- Sorry I offended you or anyone else. It wasn't my intention. What Fairy said about diet just seems obvious to me. I was responding to her (my post was specifically to her) after so many seemed so mean. I believe she is trying to be helpful. Maybe Fairy and I have a mindset similar to a Jehova's Witness because the JW's annoy so many people by coming to your door to preach but they are really only trying to spread the word about something they feel so passionate about. I personally thought that the study that Fairy posted did belong on this forum. I guess I was wrong. I don't know what comments should go on what forums anymore. If I was being offered chemo for treatment, I would have liked to read this study and I would be looking on the chemo board. Maybe this thread should have been started under the Alternative Topics but do you really think she would have gotten less flack there? When I read the topics I usually look under "active topics" and don't necessarily go to a specific forum. There are other things I would like to discuss regarding chemo topics but I don't dare because it would anger others. These discussion boards are filled with anger but I guess I can understand because I have my own anger issues (just not with the women here). It is too bad the discussion boards get so nasty. I think everyone should treat their cancer the way they see fit. More power to them. Good luck to you and everyone else.
Posts.Title: study shows chemo, radiation can cause cancer to spread Fairyfloss bluedasher

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 07:00PM baywatcher wrote: Fairyfloss- I think like you and what you say makes total sense to me. It makes so much common sense you want to spread the word. It seems so obvious but the thing you must understand is that people that think like us are in the minority. I read somewhere that the percentage of vegetarians in the US is approximately 5%. And the percentage of vegans is less than 2%. People just don't want to hear that the way they eat could contribute to cancer. They don't want to hear that the way that they eat contributes to animal cruelty, health issues and environmental issues. I know that you are writing from your heart and I thank you for it but you will be blasted if you say it anywhere but on the alternative thread. Come to think of it you will probably get blasted there too. Imagine what Dr. Campbell goes thru. I met him earlier this year and he said that spreading the word about nutrition has been a battle. He has lots of followers but also a lot of outspoken skeptics which like to argue. And the meat and dairy industry hates him. I just want you to know that I have your back. I am also on the diet and other than my depression issues, I feel healthier and am thiner than I have been in years. I used to eat dairy at practically every meal but never again. I am betting my health on this diet. Nothing else makes sense to me.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 10:53AM baywatcher wrote: Thanks ladies for your concern. I'm ok but I am a changed person. I am not on any meds at all and I won't take an anti depressant. Been there, done that.  I have tried support groups, self help books, a shrink, etc. I have read that about 25% of women that have mastectomies suffer from depression and I am just in that group. My support group was run by a retired physician who did not believe in mammograms or psa tests for men. He thinks that many women are overtreated and he thinks I was. To be honest, that info really made me spiral down to a dark place. He probably shouldn't have told me but I begged him for his opinion. He also doesn't think that I should be on an anti depressant because my depression is too specific. And it isn't just depression, it is major regret. I was just pointing out to cariboob that it is something to think about because I never did. I wouldn't recommend a mammogram to anyone, not even my girls. I have a great life but there is this deep sadness that I don't believe I will ever get over. It just wasn't worth it for me.  Don't get me wrong. If I had felt a lump I honestly don't think I would feel the same way. My diagnosis was on film so I felt nothing and I have serious doubts that it would have killed me. But I do know that it killed something inside of me.
Posts.Title: I'm a Chicken Cariboob Cariboob

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 08:59AM baywatcher wrote: When I went for my routine mammo, I was never afraid. I went for years and just thought of it as an annual check, sort of like a pap smear or a dental cleaning. So I was blindsighted when i got my call back for DCIS. I have now had a double mastectomy. Many people think I was so lucky to have caught it early. And I used to think the same thing. But let me tell you, this has affected my life in a very negative way. I went from being a positive person to a very negative one. The person that I used to be is no longer here. The depression I have had over this is just not worth it (for me). I have done much research on mammograms and I do believe that I (along with many others) was overtreated. Not a day goes by that I don't think about it. If I could do a redo, I would never have a mammogram.  You have to do what is best for you and what you can live with. I just never gave mammograms a second thought and they have changed my life. In hindsight, I would have rather have not known. I am just speaking for myself here. And probably if I was diagnosised with late stage breast cancer and never had a mammogram, I would kick myself. But I now kick myself everyday for having the mammo.

I think if ever decided to do recon, I would consider the breast center in New Orleans or someplace similar. They don't use implants but craft foobs out of your own tissue. Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 07:46PM baywatcher wrote: I think they are just being extra careful because of family history. There is an 80% or greater chance that it is nothing. Please try not to worry but I know that is easier said than done. Since you will be doing routine testing for many years, it might behoove you to look into thermograms in lieu of mammograms. Doing mammograms yearly for a long time would amount to a lot of radiation over the years. I am personally very anti mammogram. I am convinced that mammograms caused my cancer. I would never do them again but it is too late for me because both of my breasts are gone. I never questioned mammograms but I do now. It is not too late for you to do research. It is also not too late for you to consider adopting a healthy lifestyle if you don't have one already. I am talking about diet here. There is a book called "Anti-Cancer" which you may want to read. Good luck to you

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 10:52PM baywatcher wrote: Hi Streetangel- I have a bilateral, no implants. I am not handling things too well either so maybe we can work thru this together. I had my first breast removed in 04' due to a routine mammogram which showed that I had DCIS in 2 and probably 3 areas of my left breast. I was told that I needed a mastectomy because my breast had a lot of DCIS in it and I wouldn't have a lot of it left after the DCIS was removed. I didn't want to lose my breast but I didn't want to keep the breast and be put in a position later of having a later stage of cancer which is harder to manage. I kept having mammograms and 2 years later I have a scare. They do an u/s and tell me that they see a cyst. (I freaked out when I got a bad ultrasound). So my next mammo is ok and the one after (08') they find b/c again. The nightmare starts continues.. The doc told me I could have another mastectomy or a lumpectomy with rads. It was a hard decision but I didn't really like being lopsided. I could have had a lumpectomy with rads but this time I chose a mastectomy because I thought it was the smartest thing to do for my health (but I have since wondered about my decision). A bilateral mastectomy was much tougher on me that a unilateral. I had one breast for 4 years and handled the situation reasonably well. I figured I would be able to handle the loss of them both but it has not been easy. You are not far from me. I am in Key West. I know exactly how you feel. You can pm (private message) me anytime. If you want to talk, pm me your phone number and the time I should call you and I will do that.

You might want to search the threads using the key word "seroma".

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 01:51PM baywatcher wrote: Here is my opinion. If I felt a lump or had a suspicious type symptom, I would have a mammogram. But,I would not have routine mammos or routine dental xrays either. And this is coming from someone that has gone thru 2 mastectomies due to early detection. If I could turn back time, that is one thing in my life I would change. If I had felt a lump it would be different. I think there is a possibility that the mammograms caused my breast cancer. I had mammos yearly for 14 years. There was no history of breast cancer in my family. Breast cancer is big business but is is also a killer so you have to make the decision that is right for you. Bay

Posts.Title: Stupid me...DUI Stefanie Momcat1962

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 10:24AM baywatcher wrote: Kristom3- I am very sorry to hear your news. I am not stage lV and not nearly as knowledgeable as the women on this thread. I have had early stage bc twice and have been researching it like crazy for the past 6 months. Like you, I have lost some trust in doctors and want to be my own advocate. May I suggest that you consider reading "The China Study" by T. Colin Campbell. Dr. Campbell is a researcher that has studied nutrition for many years. His specialty is nutrition and cancer. He has proven that certain foods promote cancer. And yes, these foods are animal based. To simplify his findings, he compares cancer cells to grass seed. If you plant grass seed and give it no water and no sunlight, it stays dormant but when you add the water and light at a later time, the seeds begin to grow. He has proven the same with cancer. I have met Dr. Campbell and he is not trying to sell anything, he is just telling what he has learned. I hope I have been helpful to you in some small way. Many people don't believe nutrition has anything to do with cancer but it makes a lot of sense to me.

Please don't consider this surgery at this time. I am afraid that you will regret it deeply. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: y do they think this is the wrong thing to do? staceyroberts2007 hrf

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 08:48PM baywatcher wrote: Hi Otter- Double mx, no recon here. I have tattoos over my scars. My husband has totally accepted my flatness but he always loved my boobs. Sex is still the same for us. The big problem is within my head. I feel disfigured and I am depressed. I also lack confidence and I cry easily. Our marriage is not as good as it used to be and it is probably entirely my fault. I have a bad attitude and I know it but I am just not a happy person anymore and I don't seem to be able to fake it for any length of time. I don't feel sexy and I wish I had never had the mammogram. See what a downer I am?? And I have a great life that I am doing my best to ruin. I used to be a positive person. I felt a spirit leave my body shortly after my mastectomy and I am convienced that it was my positive life force. I am a negative shell of who I used to be.  Sorry for the negative feedback but it is the truth.
Posts.Title: What does your husband/loved one think about your flatness? otter otter

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 09:50PM baywatcher wrote: I have heard this too. It is known as "seeding". You can probably find some info on google under "seeding from biopsy" and you can also check the search feature on breastcancer.org under key word and type seeding. It makes sense that it is possible. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2009 09:42PM baywatcher wrote: Sue- I have recently started reading this thread. (Hi Everyone!!) I wanted to talk to you about your eye. I had an incident with my eye about 2 years ago. It hurt and made me crazy. I figured it was pink eye and tried various ointments before I finally went to an eye doctor. Turns out is it was "iritis" which is a medical emergency and you can lose your vision. It is serious!!! It has to do with the iris. I don't mean to scare you, but please get it checked.
